All Reviews

  1. I love every brush in this kit. And I really didn't expect too because I have a TON of brushes from MAC to Sigma yet I find myself reaching for my Real Techniques brushes over them. That's really what finally pushed me to just buy this set already and I'm so glad I did :) I can't emphasize enough what a steal this is. Buy it, you won't regret it.
  2. These brushes along with the purple set are just brilliant. Samantha & Real Techniques, I can't thank you enough for making brushes that are great quality and don't require you to sell organs to pay for them! In particular, I love the contour blush brush. Very versatile and picks up just the right amount of color. Also, the lip pencil is spot on. I don't know if it is the cut of the brush or the synthetic hairs but it spreads pigmented color like a dream. Great for OCC Liptars!
  3. Don buy it! I love brushes from real technique, but one brush come broken and to return it I need to pay one tax, what not compensates. Definitely I'll not buy more these brushes again on the internet, mainly here in the amazon, just in a store. Don't buy it! It can come broken for you too.
  4. Though the buffing brush is small, it applies liquid makeup like a DREAM. My face looks smooth and makeup is well blended. The other brushes are also good. They wash easily. Good value for the money.
  5. These brushes made me want to play with makeup again. For years I just used a very light coverage foundation with Bare Minerals and a bit of mascara. Once I started watching the Real Techniques/Pixi Woo videos on youtube, I decided to try some more techniques (MEDIUM coverage?? contouring?? what??) and bought a few brushes. I got hooked and my daily makeup routine hasn't been the same since. Still easy and quick, but so much better! And more fun :) These brushes are super soft, easy to use, and a HUGE bargain.

  15. I don't normally wear much makeup at all, nor do I own many makeup tools. However, I wanted to wear makeup for an event I was attending, most notably concealer for under my eyes and a bit of foundation. The problem (for me at least) is that liquid foundation leaves streaks and powder &#34;foundation&#34; looks fake. After a lot of research I decided I needed a brush and was about to purchase quite expensive brushes to get the look that I wanted. However, I decided on these brushes after watching a few videos on YouTube and reading the reviews on this site.<br /><br />What's great about these brushes is that the packaging tells you which brushes are for what application. For the novice, this simple bit of information is priceless. I used the smallest brush to conceal any dark spots, pimples, etc and the pointed brush to apply concealer around my eyes. These are the best brushes in the kit in my opinion. The largest brush works GREAT for applying all over face/neck foundation. The tip that I followed was to apply the makeup in circular and upward movements. By applying it like this, all of the makeup seeps into your pores and it looks like you aren't even wearing any. The flawless look that it gives means I have been wearing makeup more often and I actually enjoy it now.<br /><br />I seriously can't believe how cheap these brushes are. If you are on the fence, I urge you to try them. They work great and are a great intro brush for the average makeup user.
  16. not soft like i thought
  17. Love these brushes!!! It's a must have set for all beginners
  18. I just got started doing makeup and I decided to buy these brushes because they looked like they were good for beginners and easy to use. I received these the other day and I have to say, they are wonderful! They feel nice, soft, and dense. I compared these to my elf studio brushes which are super soft but have the tendency to disperse all the product on the first stroke; these have the ability to retain product and and blend it out while &#34;locking&#34; it in. When I cleaned these and tried to wipe them off, the paper towel I used was still dry because the bristles held in the water! One thing I'm not sure about, I don't know how the &#34;pointed foundation&#34; brush is an intuitive brush shape; it's nice and it can probably be used in a variety of ways but it looks like an artist's brush, which is mostly used to lay paint flat against the canvas. The need to lay a product flat against your face (rather than stippling it in) isn't very high priority for me when I'm trying to put together a natural look. Otherwise this set is just fantastic (especially the biggest brush - it's great for blending in and buffing liquid, cream, and powder foundation), and I would highly recommend these. Five stars!
  19. I was happy to find that these are Authentic Real Techniques brushes. They are soooo soft. I would repurchase!

I used my fingers to apply before and really noticed the difference when I used the buffing brush. The makeup looks a lot more natural and you're able to get more even coverage.<br /><br />The brushes are thicker than most so they cover more for a quick application. The handles have a smooth metal-like covering and soft black covering at the end of the brush so they are comfortable to hold as well. The set also comes in a nice, black travel case, which is handy.<br /><br />My favorites are the buffing brush for applying liquid foundations and detailer brush for liquid lipsticks like the OCC lip tars or other lip stains that require a precise application. They are quality brushes for an affordable price.<br /><br />They get 5 stars from me due to the design, the black case, and price.

  59. These brushes are sooo soft and durable. I've had them for a few months now and have definitely roughly washed them with soap, but they still look like new afterwards!!! Great starter brush set for someone, it has all of the essentials and you can substitute the buffing brush for a blush brush. Just make sure that you wash them at least twice a month, especially your foundation brush. Wash the base of the hairs (near the handle) of the foundation brush really well and make sure you spread the hairs apart or else you can have some left over foundation stuck there for months and not even notice it if you don't wash it properly- you'll a tough time washing it out later on if you don't .<br /> Amazing brush set for this price, can 't really get a better deal. I even think that the brushes are softer than some MAC brushes of my mom's that I've tried before. Only thing that they should fix for future editions, is making the whole handle gold- the black part tends to have foundation stains on there (from my hands) and you have to really scrub it to get it off. Besides that, I would go for it!!!

I've purchased many brush sets over the years, both expensive natural hair and synthetics, and these brushes are the softest by far.<br /><br />Buffing Brush: So thick and plush! I have very sensitive skin and I can buff and buff my SSC minerals in, and no irritation at all. And sometimes when I use a cream to powder foundation, I spritz the end of the brush lightly w/water, dip the brush into the foundation - WOW! My face looks like it's been air-brushed.<br /><br />Contour Brush: I use this for my blush 99% of the time, and the few times I use a highlighter above my cheekbone.<br /><br />Pointed Foundation Brush: I only do two-shade neutral eyes, so I use this one for the lid eye-shadow.<br /><br />Detailer Brush: This is \\"supposed\\" to be used as a concealer brush or a lipstick brush, but I use this one to apply a pearlescent highlighter on my brow bone.<br /><br />I've washed them several times and they still look good as new, and I've yet to see any shedding.<br /><br />The only thing I'm disappointed with is the case. It doesn't stand up all that easily (you pull a cord and fold it over, similar to a drawstring you'd have on the bottom of an anorak jacket). After only 2 months, the elastic bands have stretched - pockets to store the brushes would have been better.
  143. I've always wanted to purchase these because some of my friends and a lot of Youtube gurus use and rave about these brushes! The delivery was super quick and I was very happy with these brushes! I used them for the first time today and my makeup looked so flawless on my skin!!! I definitely recommend these brushes!

Especially if I use Detailer Brush to put lipstick on my lips, the tip of the brush HURT my lips! So i know this one is counterfeit. I asked amazon to send me a different set. And I can tell the different feelings when I have 2 of them on the hand. So, Buyers, don't forget to try it, ALL 4 of the brushes before deciding to keep it :)

  183. I have never owned such a nice pair of make-up brushes! They're soft on the skin and they truly do provide a much more even coverage when using liquid foundation. I am not a make-up artist or one who wears a ton of make-up, but I really like how easy these are to use.

  185. It was a present for my sister and She love it!
  186. I bought this set after purchasing the Real Techniques Stippling Brush and Expert Face brush. (I have reviews on both of those products as well, if you'd like to view those too!)<br /><br />I fell in love with the first two brushes I purchased from this brand, so I knew I just had to have the Core set. The Buffing brush in this set is my absolute favorite brush!! I have not found another buffing brush with the quality this one has! It is so soft on my sensitive skin, and picks up pressed and loose powders perfectly! They sit easily on the top of the brush without falling down next to the ferrule, which makes cleaning super easy! I have not had any shedding at all with this brush and I use it daily, as well as doing 'Sanitary Cleanings' Daily. (Using a makeup cleaning spray to spray bristles, and then wiping on tissue to get product I just used off.) I also deep clean/shampoo my brushes once a week, sometimes twice depending on what products I use, and I still have not witnessed any shedding and I have had this set for quite awhile!<br /><br />The Contour Brush is my second favorite in this set. The length and shape of the bristles are perfect for what it's intended use is. Again; these soft, plush, synthetic bristles pick product up easily and truly make for a beautiful finish. Cleaning this brush, is also super easy! No shedding so far with this brush either! As well as contouring with this brush, I also like to use it for highlighting. It's the perfect shape for highlighting under my eyes, above my brow, and on the tops of my cheeks! I use this brush with powder and creme bronzers and/or highlighters!<br /><br />My third fave brush in this set is the detailer brush (the smallest brush). I use this brush after I have applied my foundation to smooth my liquid out under my eyes, so it wont settle into my wrinkles under eye; as well as the corners of my nose so my foundation doesn't look cakey in those tight corners. I clean this brush with my makeup brush sanitary cleaner (the spray/tissue method) daily. Since the brush is so small, I don't normally do deep cleanings because I don't dip the tips in any product, rather I just smooth the bristles over product in few areas of my face. You could also use this brush to apply lipsticks, as you would a lipstick brush. It's the perfect size for that if you have a lip compact vs an actual lipstick.<br /><br />My least favorite brush is the foundation brush. To be honest, I haven't even used this brush at all yet. It just stays in the brush pouch. I have never seen a foundation brush that small! It is super small, more like a concealer brush than a foundation brush. I guess I don't too much mind though, since I don't apply my foundation with those kind of brushes. I like to use UD's Optical Blurring Brush. (It's ahhh-mazing for liquid foundations!) So, this poor lil guy just sits in the pouch until I can find some use for it, or maybe if one of my friends wants it.<br /><br />All, in all, I do love Real Techniques brushes! It comes with a pouch, that you can use to sit upright on your counter (Like in the picture of the product), but I've never used it that way. It doesn't really seem practical. I have other ways of storing brushes, like in vanity cups, or my acrylic vanity organizers. So, like the foundation brush, the pouch is hidden away and doesn't get used either. Another good point to mention about these brushes is the way they are made. They all are pretty round and have a big base with a flat bottom, so when you are applying your makeup and switch to another brush, you can sit the brush upright on your counter and don't have to lay it flat. This is good if you plan on using the brush again during the same makeup application so you don't have to lay it down with product on and get bacteria, dirt, etc onto the bristles and put it back on your face. Yuk! Who wants that? All the brushes are also labeled on the handles so you will never forget what kind of brush itis, and they also have Samantha Chapman's beautiful signature on the handle in pretty writing. The colors of the brushes are very beautiful as well! I love the bright golds, pinks, and purples! It makes for a great makeup brush collection!<br /><br />One unfortunate thing about this set is that you can NOT buy these brushes separately! Big Frown! I would love to have a couple more of the Buffing Brushes and another Contour brush. Unfortunately, if I want another one, I would have to buy the whole set again. This means another pouch and ridiculously small foundation brush hiding in my drawer. But, I guess it's good marketing done by Real Techniques...more money, right?!<br /><br />There are many more brushes I anticipate on trying from this line because I have fallen so deeply in love with the ones I have. Honestly, these brushes are high end quality, with a Wal-Mart budget! *wink wink* I highly recommend Real Techniques to all my friends, family, and whomever is reading this! You wont regret it! Your makeup brush collection will thank you, as well as your face!!<br /><br />xoxo J.McCranie

The contour brush is small so its great at placing the bronzer exactly where you want it and blend effortlessly. I cannot speak about the other two brushes.

  217. Nice brush set! I work as a make up artist and use the face brush as my foundation brush personally. The sigma brush is almost twice as expensive as this entire set, so if you are just looking for personal use or want a good set of brushes to start out with I'd recommend the set. the small detailer brush is also nice for some inner corner highlighting, and the other two brushes I use for concealer and to gently brush off fall out eye shadow fro under the eyes, or to set foundation with powder on smaller areas. One point deduction, because if you clean these brushes twice a week with rubbing alcohol and brush cleaner the glue will dissolve over time and the bristles will shed, BUT this took almost a year for me and since I work with make up I do clean those brushes a lot more than a person that just uses these brushes for themselves. Personally, I don't think you necessarily need the other brushes, unless you are really into make up. If you are simply looking for a nice foundation brush for a great value this real Techniques set is a wonderful choice!

I think that it can definitely have many uses. Lastly, the buffing brush- I use it for blush, I find that the real techniques blush brush is far too large, especially since I'm not a huge blush fan to begin with. The &#34;concealer brush&#34; works great on blemishes. LOVE the &#34;buffer brush&#34; it's my favorite for foundation, I use it with NARS SheerGlow and it blends it in nicely. The &#34;foundation brush&#34; is probably the one I use lease. Every brush dries fairly fast when deep cleaned, no shedding, and keeps its shape. I am considering purchasing a second set because I love it so much.
  420. I bought this set for the buffing brush and contour brush. I have used the foundation and concealer brush (as a lip brush) as well but not on an everyday basis. I use the buffing brush for all foundations (liquid and powder) and bb creams. I use the contour brush for contour as well as powder blush. I love how the white tips let you see how much product there is on the brush. The case is nice for travelling and is also good for drying the brushes after washing. Make sure the brush tip is facing the ground so that water doesn't collect in the brush handle. No loose hairs so far (~2 months)!
  421. I don't use these brushes professionally, but I use them for everyday use. They are very good considering the brushes I had before them. I think they will end up lasting a long time too.

I have washed these brushes many times and there was very minimal shedding. I made the mistake of tossing the black brush holder but it can also be used as a brush drying rack if you turn it upside down. I think this is an excellent brush set for the price and I have bought myself a set and given one out as a gift as well. I highly recommend this brand!   445. I've used brushes in the past that had celebrity names and made all kinds of claims before proceeding to lose bristles during routine use or cleaning with solution.   446. I bought the Expert Face Brush and was impressed by the quality of the brush so I decided to buy this product. I honestly think that you are getting your money's worth for this. Usually a drugstore brush is around $8-$10 dollars, but you get four products for the price of two. I bought this solely for the contour brush, but surprisingly loving the buffing brush as well.<br />I use the contour brush to apply both my blush and bronzer. It doesn't soak up too much of the powder between the bristles. It also prevents me from using too much of the product on my skin. It makes it easy to blend out the product so I don't get streaks on my face.<br />The buffing brush is used for my face pressed and mineral powders. I heard it can also be used for liquid foundations, but I didn't try that yet.<br />I haven't gotten a lot of use from the foundation brush because it's so small. It would take a long time to cover my entire face. I might use it to apply concealer though. The not-so-apparent usefulness of this brush is the reason why I'm docking a star off the rating.<br />The lip brush is good. No complaints. I had a mini one from a lip palette so I was glad to get a new one with a full sized handle.<br />Overall, the quality is good and the bristles are soft. Don't try to skimp out on brushes because they need to last a long time. I regret buying elf brushes now that I have these in my collection. It also beats out my ecotools brushes. So if you don't want to spend a lot on luxury brushes, try real Techniques.<br />(Note: The price on Amazon was cheaper than my local Walgreens so I bought it online)

  540. These are so soft and they are so great for putting on makeup. They help create whatever effect I am going for and they don't cost an arm and a leg. Love them!
  541. Good...very handy. This brush set is really good..had it for 2months and no complaints yet..I hope I have none though
  542. Detailer Brush - Smallest brush in the kit. I use this brush to apply lip tar and sometimes concealer. It's nice. It has a pointy end for very precise application.<br /><br />Pointed Foundation Brush - Nah. Out of the entire range of RT brushes, this is one of the ones I've used the least. It's really small. I feel it's way too small for foundation. It's more of a specialized kind of brush that could be used for getting foundation in a tricky place, applying highlighter, applying concealer, or possibly blending. I don't use this brush at all.<br /><br />Buffing Brush - I use this brush every day. I use it to apply foundation, powder, powder foundation, bronzer, blush, highlighter, contour, or to just blend away edges. Extremely versatile and a good size.<br /><br />Contour Brush - I use this a few times a month. It's great for contouring under the jaw, but I find it too fluffy to contour my cheeks, nose, forehead, or chin. It does the job, but I prefer using my Becca paddle brush to contour, and my RT buffing brush to blend it.<br /><br />Panoramic 2-in-1 brush case/stand - Meh, I tossed this because I found it a pain to use. I didn't like that it was always open and that my brushes weren't sealed off from the outside environment when the case was closed. I would prefer if they came in a case like the Sigma brushes, or if they included a cute little bag to keep them in, but that's just me. I don't like having to put each brush back into a specific place, and I feel like this gets dirty and isn't easy to clean.<br /><br />I've had the full set of these brushes since they first launched in 2012. Since getting them, I've used at least three of them every single day. That's two years of constant use, and they look and preform the same way they did the day I received them. Since getting the full line of these, I have not purchased a single new brush. My old mac brushes lay untouched in the back of my drawer. Not to mention that just one Mac brush costs as much as the whole set of these ones. Did I mention that you can now buy these at Walmart?<br /><br />These brushes are superior to animal hair brushes in every way. They are cruelty free. They are extremely easy to clean-- I timed myself, and I can wash twenty brushes in seven minutes. They do not get stained. I purposely didn't clean red OCC Lip Tar off of my lip brush for a month, and the lip tar came off as easily as any other product. (I use Trader Joe's Tea Tree Body Wash or just regular Equate hand soap to clean mine.) They don't hold any funky smells or bacteria after washing, since the bristles aren't porous, unlike animal hair bristles. For the same reason, they dry off very fast. My RT face brush takes about 30 minutes to dry if I leave it damp on a washcloth, and I can dry it almost completely in a few seconds if I rub the brush against a sham. I've cleaned and dried my brushes right before using them to do my makeup regularly. My mac brushes take hours (sometimes days) to dry completely, even if I wipe them against a sham first. Another advantage of the non-porous bristles is that you don't have to condition them. After washing animal hair brushes, you are supposed to condition them with an oil or conditioner so they stay soft and don't get brittle. If you don't, your brushes will start shedding. The RT brushes don't need to be conditioned, and they don't shed.<br /><br />Then, they are soft. Softer than animal hair. They pick up product and dispense it with ease. Product doesn't linger in the brush nearly as much it does on animal hair brushes, which lets me use less product. Truly a pleasure to use and apply makeup with. My one small gripe is that sometimes product can get stuck on the black grip part of these brushes, but that is hardly an issue since it cleans right off. They just might look a bit dirty after rolling around in your makeup bag.<br /><br />These are so durable and have held up better than any brush I've ever had before. As I said before, I've beenusing them for two years already and they look and feel the same way they did the day I got them. I'm sure that they will last for years to come. I would give these to a friend. I would repurchase. Affordable, durable, just a great product. These would be a great gift to anyone that wears makeup. I would recommend these over any other brush on the market. I feel that this is a truly superior product in every way.using them for two years already and they look and feel the same way they did the day I got them. I'm sure that they will last for years to come. I would give these to a friend. I would repurchase. Affordable, durable, just a great product. These would be a great gift to anyone that wears makeup. I would recommend these over any other brush on the market. I feel that this is a truly superior product in every way.

I'm happy to say I had a better experience with the real technique brushes. I use the small concealer one the most and the contour one the least. The bristles are super soft on all four brushes, which is nice because I have sensitive skin, so it doesn't feel prickly and it doesn't irritate me. The only issue I have is with the powder foundation brush. I think the mineral powder from my Bare Minerals foundation is too fine because a lot of it ends up falling out. As a tip, try to swirl the brush around your face. That gives the best application for powder/mineral foundation. Overall, really happy with these brushes and will be purchasing more!

  714. What a lovely little brush set. Here's how I use them, going from left to right<br /><br />Brush #1 (contour) I use this for blush and bronzer on my cheeks.Precise application.<br /><br />Brush #2 (foundation) I use this in conjunction with my fingers to apply foundation. I dip the brush in the lid of my liquid, and paint it on my problem areas, and then blend it out with my fingers.<br /><br />Brush #3 (concealer): I use this to apply my lipstick. My lips are a weird, full shape, and I have trouble being precise with merely the bullet. I apply as much as I can straight from the bullet, and then I blend and smooth the product with the brush.<br /><br />Brush #4 (powder?): I rarely put product on this brush, instead I use it for buffing. It works beautifully at buffing away any eye shadow fallout. I also use it at the end of my routine if anything in my foundation needs &#34;smoothed over&#34; so to speak.

One day I decided to use it to buff in my under eye concealir and I just fell in love with its ability. The sharp pointed angle allows me to leave a crisp line at the outer corner of my eye and it buffs out shadow fall out beautifully. Now it is one of the brushes I use every day. But what I use it for most is for placing cream eyecshadows as a brow highlighter or at the inner tear ducts of my eyes. I love the quality. I have washed them once a month for the last year and daily with a brush cleaner and they are still in fabulous condition. These are well worth the money spent considering some brands sell one brush for the price of this whole set. I am so glad I found this brand I purchased all the brush sets and individual ones sold. The buffing brush gives such a great finish with my liquid foundation and application is a breeze. I REALLY love it. However, the RT expert face brush is almost the exact same brush, and I have actually heard many say they prefer this brush over the buffing.<br /><br />All that being said, the expert face brush is like $9 which I would have rather gotten than this set for $18. The only reason I use the other brushes is to justify my buying them, I have many brushes that do the same thing.. So knowing what I know now, I would buy the expert face brush for half the price and not end up with practically useless brushes that take up space.

  907. Do I sound a little over the top? Maybe. But these brushes for the cost of just $15 for 4 are a STEAL. First of all, lets talk quality. They are HIGH QUALITY synthetic brushes. I've washed and dried them properly over a dozen times without any shedding or quality loss. And the brush case? Convenient!!! Doubles as a stand? GENIUS. The ferrule is covered, making the design attractive and no more wobbly ferrules!!! Also they are lightweight and feels like a quality product in your hand. I'm going to go over the pro's and cons of each brush.<br /><br />Contour Brush - I use this mainly for highlighter but can work very well as a contour brush with bronzer. Love how it picks up my powder highlighter and it's very easy and precise to apply.<br /><br />Foundation Brush - Way too tiny for foundation! If you use for foundation (which I've done once) it spreads it nice and soft but it will take you all day. So I recommend you use this for concealer which by the way works great. Since these bristles are synthetic, they also don't soak up product which means more product will end up on your face and less wasted on the brush.<br /><br />Detailer Brush - I don't have much use for this brush except to highlight the corners of my eyes or lipstick. It also can conceal small areas. All in all, good to have!<br /><br />Buffer Brush - If this set only came with this ONE BRUSH, it would be worth it!!! This brush is OMG that good. So if you go on YouTube and search for &#34;Real Techniques Buffer Brush&#34; you will find lots of people reviewing it and using it FOR FOUNDATION. Whaaaat? You may say? Yes, foundation. Don't knock it until you try it! I was skeptical, but used once and have been hooked ever since! Why is it that good? Because the super soft bristles BUFFS the foundation into your skin as you apply and gives an airbrushed appearance. You can also sort of stipple on product and then buff. Work in small areas especially with drugstore foundation which in my opinion covers well but dries fast. You can also use this for mineral foundation, cream foundation and blush. It's a multi-tasker!<br /><br />I added other Real Techniques to my collection - such as the &#34;Expert Face Brush&#34; and &#34;Stippling Brush&#34; but I keep going back to the buffer brush!<br /><br />Bottom line - high quality, great value. Great as presents too! You will NOT regret this purchase!!!

They really blend everything perfectly, like no other brush I've owned (Stila, Trish McKevoy, Sephora- terrible!, etc etc etc). Although budget friendly, none of the fibers or hairs fall out and I love that they are vegan/no animal testing. I never knew that brushes could make such a big difference to the look of my makeup, I always just bought the expensive ones. These are dense, but super soft for the ultimate, seamless blend. My mineral foundation (just switched back) has never looked so good- the larger brush included here is my favorite (I even own her stippling brush, but prefer this one for minerals). Before, minerals sort of sat on top of my skin, now they blend beautifully and seamlessly. I don't like a heavy makeup look, I like it to look natural, but I love great cosmetics and skincare.   970. This set includes 4 brushes, all made with soft Taklon bristles. The brushes are sturdy and wash well.<br /><br />- Buffing Brush: I love this brush for BB cream and Tinted Moisturizer.<br />- Foundation Brush: This flat foundation brush is tiny. I don't use it for foundation. I sometimes use this for concealer, although I prefer the flat brush in the travel set for that purpose.<br />- Detailer Brush: Nice little brush if you have extra time. I use it to apply stick concealer to cover blemishes and to add extra concealer to the small spaces around my nose. This is great for detail work. However, I don't use it that much since I usually apply stick concealer directly to my face.<br />- Contouring brush: This can be used for highlighter. It's nice but not something I use every day. It's too small for bronzer and I don't always use highlighter.<br />- Case: The case is too small for travel or for at home use. I use far too many brushes for this case and they simply won't fit.<br /><br />Why only 4.5 stars? Not every brush is an every day brush and the case is useless. I wish you could buy the Buffing Brush separately as that is hands down the most useful brush in the set. However, since I also frequently use the Contouring brush, I think the set is worth the money.<br /><br />Update: It is now September 2015, so I've had this set for 2 years. I use 2 of the 4 brushes in this kit. I haven't used the detailer brush in at least a year. Same with the foundation brush. The buffing brush is still good for tinted moisturizer. I don't use it much, but I do use it and like it. The star of this set is actually the contour brush! I use that brush virtually every day to blend in concealer. It really is perfect for that purpose! I wish I used more of the brushes, but for the price 2 out of 4 isn't that bad!

Especially the stippling and buffing brush. I plan to expand my collection. Also, if you get any of the traveling sets, you can use the holder to dry your brushes. Be sure to have your brush hairs pointing downward. Genius design!<br /><br />**UPDATE** It has been one year since I purchased this set. Still in same form as day 1 condition despite my inclination to deep clean each brush after each use. Well worth the investment. I saw that another reviewer preferred EcoTools over Real Techniques. I would have to differ in opinion. I have purchased an EcoTools travel set & bronzing brush about a year ago as well -- the durability is not the same. The metal cuff binding the hair to the bamboo shafts came off on multiple brushes; I have not purchased any EcoTool product since.
  1029. I got this brush set and I did expect a bit more. The Pixiwoo sisters seem to use them more efficiently for some reason. I am learning to work with these a bit better and I am liking them more each time. The buffing brush is good for liquid foundation but I prefer the stippling one because its dense but not too dense like the buffing. I like the contouring brush as well, its a good standard size for most people. The foundation flat brush is too small so you can use it for concealer. The small detailer brush I think can be used for gel liners or lining eyes with eyeshadow. Overall I would give this a 3.5 out of 5. I must say that the Blush Brush which does not come with this set is great for overall powder and not blush. This is because its not too dense as you would like it to be. But I still recommend purchasing it with this collection. The Real Techniques foundation and face brushes do not shed which is a great aspect that you should consider. The quality is very good. Synthetic brushes usually do not pick up much color though as well as natural hair bristles. But once you get used to it, it should be fine. I would recommend watching YouTube videos to make sure that you know what these are like to have.

It would take you for ever to cover your face with that and the coverage would be terrible. I still have not found a good use for that one. The contour brush can definitely be used as a blush brush. The small detail brush (I think it might be a concealer brush) is too small for concealer but I find that it is good for eyeshadow detail (highlighting the inner corner or the outer v). The buffing brush is the star of this collection. It is great at buffing in liquid foundation and I have also used it for powder foundation.

  1059. Both Ecotools and Real Techniques come from the same company - Paris Presents Incorporated, and both use soft, synthetic hair (a good thing - no cruelty involved).<br /><br />To be completely honest, it seems that the differences are in the design, colors and price. Ecotools has a very simple/basic design, while Real Techniques looks much fancier (especially its brushes' handles). I would buy Real Techniques as a present - it looks good.<br /><br />Apart from that, I actually find Ecotools to be of about the same quality and softness - or even better.<br /><br />Well, the other difference is the price (in most cases, you can find Ecotools brushes for about half price of the Real Techniques ones).<br /><br />UPDATE:<br /><br />I wash my brushes regularly - the Ecotools ones have remained the same, however the Real Techniques' handles have deteorated. The black parts of the handles became somehow wrinkly (the golden part stayed intact). Expected them to be more durable due as they are more expensive than Ecotools.
  1060. I really like these brushes. They are made by the same company that makes Ecotools. I prefer Ecotools. But these are pretty good brushes. I wish that the font on the side was engraved so that the letters don't rub off. It's a minor detail, but I am a bit OCD and that stuff annoys me. Overall these are great brushes and Sam's videos on Real Techniques as well as on the Pixiwoo channel will help you understand how to use them. I think it's great for people who are just getting into make-up as well as those who are experienced. The bristles are very very soft on the skin and durable.
  1061. I love Sam's tutorials online and also found these brushes to be amazing. They don't break down under constant washing or sanitizing!   1081. Overall this is a very good set in both quality and price. The contour brush is amazing. It fits right in the hollow of your cheeks, and the softness to stiffness ratio is great for a achieving an even blend (no 80's make up look here). The multitask brush is also great for both foundation and blush. The foundation brush included here I don't really have much use for. I find that these types of foundation brushes don't give the best application. I also don't really have a use for the concealer brush. I can see myself maybe using it when I want to use a liquid base for my contour, as they do provide a precise application for that.   1082. i love all the realtechniques brush range, whenever im looking around on the high street they are so expensive !! excellent price excellent quality !!
  1083. These set of brushes is great for beginners and for other makeup artist out there. It is cheap and affordable and great quality. I'll review each brush on it's own.<br /><br />The first brush I will review is the buff brush (it might not be called that but it is the brush on the far right in the picture). It is very similar to a dense flat top kabuki brush and I use this more for my foundation for a more natural feel/affect. I find this brush is amazing for all the different foundations out there. The dense brush helps the foundation buff into the skin better making the foundation blend better and look more natural.<br /><br />The concealer brush is smaller than normal concealer brushes that are offered at sephora and other brands. However, I live the size because the amount of control it gives making it easier to get into the creases or spot treating a certain area. I think it does the best to make it easier to blend and mix the right shade in a concealer palette.<br /><br />The foundation brush is not my most favorite because like I said I use the the buffing brush more for foundation purposes. This brush is still great because the tip makes it easy to blend near your eye and making sure you are able to get the foundation is the smallest spots.<br /><br />Last is the dome shape brush. This brush I usually use for powder, bronzer, and blush. The angle that the dome brush gives makes it easier to slip under the hollows of your cheek to help contour your cheekbones which makes it a good brush to use your bronzer. The size of the brush helps you to not make your application like you are striping color onto your face and makes it easier to blend. I guess if you want to make application quicker I guess you can use a powder brush but I think that this brush can do that as well.<br /><br />The brushes did not shed when I cleaned them and I've been using it for quite some time. If you take even better car I am sure that they will last even longer<br /><br />This is my ownpersonal thoughts I am not a makeup artist or makeup expert, this is my experience when handling these brushes.

  1130. This is a nice set of brushes for flawless application. The buffing brush is by far my favorite in the kit. You can use it to apply and buff in foundation, apply face powder, blush, bronzer and contour. It's just so versatile! The contour brush is a little more pointed and tapered and works nicely to set concealer, highlight and contour. I've never been a fan of flat foundation brushes but that's just a matter of personal preference. The brush head on the pointed foundation brush is quite a bit smaller than most other brushes of its kind but it does the job. It's a nice brush to use for spot concealing especially larger areas as well. The tapered tip helps blend product to make it look more natural. There's also a really small brush in this kit, the detailer brush, which is useful to conceal small areas or to highlight under brows and the inner corners of the eyes. The detailer brush can also be used to line the lash line as well as work as a lip brush. The kit also comes in a handy brush case that folds back to form a brush stand with slots for additional brushes. The brush hair on all brushes are very soft and comfortable on skin. A detailed review and photos are available on my blog: [...]

The foundation brush is too small and thin for me to use, personally.   1276. I was in the market for new makeup brushes, and in the 15 years since I last bought my set of MAC brushes, their prices have gone up exponentially...out of my price range. So, I did my research, looking for makeup brushes that were excellent quality, were a nice weight in my hands, didn't shed, were affordable, and were attractive. I knew I could always buy a case, but if the new brushes came in a nice case, that would be a bonus. Everything I read put Real Techniques in the top 5 brands for the things that I was searching for. So I bought this set, the Travel Essentials Set, and a Stippling Brush. When they came (in a timely manner!), I washed them with brush shampoo and let them air dry, prior to first use. 24 hours later I put the brushes to the test, and they EXCEEDED my expectations! Well constructed brushes in well made cases (I can even easily fit the Stippling Brush in the Core Essentials case!), the quality is exceptional, there's no shedding (I use them daily, and spritz them with Brush Cleaner after each, then gently wipe dry), they feel very nice in my hands, and they are beautiful to boot! For the price, you just can't beat these brushes. I'll be back to buy the set for the eyes, and that will complete my set! I've had them now for a few weeks and they have not disappointed me at all! I have not had one brush shed even a little, and they hold their shape! DO NOT GET SEDUCED BY THE \\"35 BRUSH SETS FOR $17!\\"! Most of us, who wear makeup regularly use roughly 12-13 brushes...so I bought what I needed, paid only a little more than those cheap sets that contain too many brushes to keep track of, let alone use, and got EVERYTHING I WANTED!! As an extra plus, the official website has tutorials on how to use each brush, and how to achieve certain looks with makeup. I don't normally use these, but I had no idea how to use a Stippling Brush (I just knew that it was for foundation, and used to achieve the \\"airbrushed\\" look), so I watched that tutorial, and I'm so glad I did! I really do have that airbrushed look now, AND I use less foundation (about 3/4 less than I had with a flat foundation brush)!! Thank you Real Techniques!!!!

  1381. These brushes are easy to use and versatile. Watch the video from the company's website for a detailed demonstration of each brush. They are easy to maintain. (Buff excess product onto a clean cloth/tissue, or spritz cloth with a solvent based brush cleaner, then buff the brush head until clean for daily maintenance. Shampoo for deeper cleaning.)<br /><br />I bought these brushes just to have the Contour brush for blush, for its' petite size and unique shape. (For working a small area.) The rest of the collection ended up impressing me as well.<br /><br />The Contour brush is great for blush when you do not have a large area to apply (think apple of the cheek only and then another color for the contour of the cheek bone). I use it for highlighting and for easy eye shadow base color application. (I use my the Balm highlighter for both.) You can just utilize the tip for shading your brow bone.<br /><br />The Pointed Foundation brush is excellent for corrector/concealer. It navigates around the eye area with precision and is gentle to the skin. Utilizing its' point to apply corrector around the mouth and nose works perfectly. (I have another brush I really like for foundation because it covers more area with every swipe.)<br /><br />The Detailer brush can be used for general concealing, lips, or eyes. I use it mainly to apply shadow to the tear-duct area of eyes for highlighting. Then I finish my eye make-up application by sweeping the brush under the lower lashes to `clean-up' a bit, `fanning-out' a bit on the outside of the eye (with whatever residual product is left on the brush).<br /><br />The Buffing brush works well as designed, but admittedly, gets used much less than the others. Works well for apply bronzer around hairline. 12/03/12 New--saw tutorial using this brush for cream to powder foundation application, works very well, gets used much more now.<br /><br />Bottom line: This Core Collection, is just that, the core brushes to make precision application effortless.

  1390. The 'real techniques' brand makes really quality products at really low prices. It also helps to know these brushes are endorsed by a makeup artist who is REALLY popular on youtube (pixiwoo), and does really nice work. She uses her brushes often while applying the makeup, so you know that it isn't something that doesn't work, and is worth the money. If it's good enough for a high-profile makeup artist, I guess it's good enough for me. This set in particular is my favorite because you get a little of everything you need. You can put on foundation/primer with one, eyeshadow with another, blush with one, and concealer/highlighter with another. They are very soft, synthetic bristles, which means they last longer and you can clean them more often than animal hair products. I've had these for about two weeks, I've washed them once, and I haven't noticed any hairs falling out. The handles are metal, so you are getting a really durable product. I like the white coloring at the top because then you know you've cleaned them well. I recently bought another brush from sephora's line, and it really doesn't come close to these!<br /><br />Added bonus- they come in a carrying case and they are labeled for people like me who are totally new to makeup and has no idea WHAT is going on. Also, if you need helpful tips on applying or cute looks for a job interview or night out, you can check out pixiwoo on youtube, which is fun to watch and really informative.

  1417. Love these brushes :) the handles are very easy to grip and the bristles work amazingly with any profuct and blend beautifully
  1418. I'm very happy with these brushes. I have only ever used cheaper brushes (and never natural hair) so I don't have a ton of experience to compare these to, but I find them to be very satisfactory. I wish all the handles tapered a little more, but they're designed to stand up so they are fat all the way down. They get a little bulky in my brush cup for this reason- especially since I have a couple other large RT brushes. All of those big bases take up a lot of room. The brushes wash well and I have not lost a single hair in 5 or so washings. I use the contouring brush for contouring and blush (I need to get the blush brush stat!); I use the flat foundation brush for concealer because it is tiny, I use the detail brush for lips or spot concealer, depending, and I use the buffing brush to smooth and blend everything out. I think the brushes are a little odd looking by themselves but once I added the eye set and a couple others, they all look cute together.<br /><br />The case is super useless, so I laugh when people point out how great it is in video reviews. It sucks. The only time it would be good is if you're traveling, but a standard case would work just as well because the stand is lame. It's a good concept but the brushes are really hard to remove from the elastic, especially with their rubberized bases; the case is flimsy, cheap and lightweight, and it would be a PITA to put each brush back in the elastic. However, I have discovered that people will actually buy these cases on ebay. So I was able to make a bit of money back on each of the sets I have (this one and the eye set). The case concept might be a good idea in heavy leather with better quality elastic- then you wouldn't have to hold down the case to pull each brush out.
